title.native: デジモンアドベンチャー０２

description: A few years after the adventures of the Chosen Children in the Digital World, a new batch of Chosen Children are summoned to save the Digital World. An evil ruler known as the Digimon Kaiser, or Digimon Emperor, is forcing the Digital World's Digimon into enslavement. The new group of Chosen Children, with the help of their Digimon, then begin a journey to stop the evil Digimon Emperor.

tags.name: Primarily Child Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters below a high school age.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

tags.name: Primarily Animal Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed animal or animal-like characters.

tags.name: Virtual World
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the world inside a video game.

tags.name: Alternate Universe
tags.description: Features multiple alternate universes in the same series.

tags.name: Anthropomorphism
tags.description: Contains non-human character(s) that have attributes or characteristics of a human being.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Dragons
tags.description: Prominently features mythical reptiles which generally have wings and can breathe fire.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Dinosaurs
tags.description: Prominently features Dinosaurs, prehistoric reptiles that went extinct millions of years ago.

tags.name: Proxy Battle
tags.description: A proxy battle is a battle where humans use creatures/robots to do the fighting for them, either by commanding those creatures/robots or by simply evolving them/changing them into battle mode.

node.description:
__[Website](http://www.steveblumvoices.com) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/blumspew) | [Instagram](http://instagram.com/blumspew) | [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/SteveBlumVoices/) | [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@blumspew) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/user/Voiceactor1/)__

An American voice actor known primarily for his work in anime dubs and video games. Fans of Cartoon Network's Toonami can recognize Blum's voice as TOM, the block's robotic host. He was also the voice of 7-Eleven's "Oh thank heaven" television and radio advertisements.Steven is currently the "disembodied voice"" of the podcast show http://goanimetv.com/ also works with Vic Mignogna making parodies of Budweiser's audio commercials called "real fans of genius".

A veteran of the voice-over business, Steve Blum cut his vocal teeth in the industry, on anime shows like Guyver and Giant Robo, and since has voiced hundreds of diverse characters in productions representing every media imaginable!   Steve's training was highly unorthodox by industry standards. Before voice acting became a full-time profession, Steve worked in a book store, a pet store, an auto-parts store, serviced fire protection equipment, ran a mailroom, drove a delivery truck, managed warehouses, became an international film and video sales/service coordinator, copywriter and marketing executive for a sci-fi film company, an ADR script writer, part-time musician...

But where's the acting experience? All on the job. It started with a few monster growls, then a couple of old men's lines, a hero or two... thousand - and the rest is history. More than 15 years later, he's out there soiling microphones and barking, spitting, and yowling his way into your lives every day and actually making a living at it!

[Profile (Aoni)](https://www.aoni.co.jp/search/maeda-ai.html) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ai_max)

Married to [Ryoutarou Okiayu](https://anilist.co/staff/95177/Ryoutarou-Okiayu)

_Not to be confused with the model and actress [Ai Maeda](https://anilist.co/staff/95647) who has only voiced Kino._

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

Yoshida has written and supervised numerous scripts for anime series, live-action dramas and films. Her major works include [Kaleido Star](https://anilist.co/anime/427), [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477), [Maria-sama ga Miteru](https://anilist.co/anime/158), [D.Gray-man](https://anilist.co/anime/1482), [K-On!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680), [Bakuman](https://anilist.co/anime/7674) and [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131). In more recent works, she has supervised the screenplays for [Majestic Prince](https://anilist.co/anime/15863), [Non Non Biyori](https://anilist.co/anime/17549), [A Town Where You Live](https://anilist.co/anime/17741), [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417), [Yowamushi Pedal](https://anilist.co/anime/18179) and [Castle Town Dandelion](https://anilist.co/anime/20951). In films, she wrote the screenplay for Ghibli's [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597), the original films that would make up [Digimon: The Movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2961), Kyoto Animation’s hit anime film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954), and the film adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's [Buddha](https://anilist.co/anime/7014), the last one's [second film](https://anilist.co/anime/20500) was given a stamp of approval by the Dalai Lama.

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. In 2018, she wrote the screenplay for [Violet Evergarden](https://anilist.co/anime/21827) which aired on TV in Japan and is licensed by Netflix.

Yoshida also wrote the story for the manga series [Tokyo Mew Mew](https://anilist.co/manga/30554).

(Source: Wikipedia)

He's credited on all relevant media as the creator of the original concept and character designs for the virtual pet franchise, Digimon. However, nothing is known about Hongo as an individual.

The name is actually a pseudonym for the three most important figures in the creation of the Digimon franchise: Aki Maita, one of the two creators of the original Tamagotchi; Hiroshi Izawa, the author of the first Digimon manga; and Takeichi Hongo, the director of marketing for Bandai.

(Source: Digimon Wikia)

[Website](http://www.konaka.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/yamaki_nyx)

Chiaki J. Konaka is a Japanese writer and scenarist best known for shows such as [Serial Experiments Lain](https://anilist.co/anime/339/), [Digimon Tamers](https://anilist.co/anime/874/) and [Texhnolyze](https://anilist.co/anime/26/). He is also known to be the creator of Ultraman Gaia, as cited by Tsuburaya Productions.

Konaka's serious works generally have a dark, psychological tone. As a Cthulhu Mythos writer, he tends to add Lovecraftian elements to his works.

"Chiaki J. Konaka" is a very unusual name, as Japanese names typically do not include middle names. Konaka states that the "J." evokes the "Christian" name "John", due to him being born to parents who were members of the Anglican Church, but he does not identify as Christian. He began using the "J." at the age of 12, when he began making 8 mm films; he patterned the style after Western names such as "Charles M. Schulz".

He has cited [Ghost Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/2596/) as his favorite screenwriting project.

[Website](http://wadakoji.com/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/和田光司)

Kouji Wada was best known for performing several songs for the [Digimon](https://anilist.co/anime/552/) series.

On April 3, 2016, he suddenly passed away due to complications related to nasopharynx cancer.

[Website](http://wadakoji.com/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/和田光司)

Kouji Wada was best known for performing several songs for the [Digimon](https://anilist.co/anime/552/) series.

On April 3, 2016, he suddenly passed away due to complications related to nasopharynx cancer.

Takanori Arisawa was a Japanese composer and arranger from Tokyo. He wrote the background music for several notable anime, including the award-winning soundtrack of the Sailor Moon anime series.    He died of bladder cancer at 54 years of age.    As the Music Director for Sailor Moon, Arisawa's first award was the 1993 Golden Disk Grand Prize from Columbia Records. He continued to compose for the entire anime series, plus several video games and some of the stage musicals. In 1998, 2000, and 2001 he won the JASRAC International Award for most international royalties, owing largely to the popularity of Sailor Moon music in other nations.    Arisawa expressed an admiration of Hollywood-style music, drawing his initial inspiration for the tone of the Sailor Moon soundtrack from the Charlie's Angels TV series. He frequently made use of symbolism when writing themes for specific characters or groups, borrowing thematic elements from diverse genres and from other countries. As the series progressed, his music gravitated from a pop feeling toward more classical arrangements to represent the protagonist having passed through painful experiences and grown as a person.    Source: Wikipedia

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/中鶴勝祥)

Originating from [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/). Most known for his work in the [Digimon](https://anilist.co/anime/552/) franchise.
__[Website](http://www.amy.hi-ho.ne.jp/s-nishizono/)__

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/cher_vOwO)

__Cher Watanabe__ is a Japanese musician, composer, arranger and keyboardist.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oja0222digi)

Affiliated with [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/) since 1987.

[Seki-sensei](https://anilist.co/character/14098/) in [Ojamajo Doremi](https://anilist.co/anime/350/) is named after her.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kakudou) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/角銅博之)

Hiroyuki Kakudou, also known as Hiroki Kudou, is a Japanese anime director. He is best known for directing the first two Digimon series.

Kakudou is a graduate of Tokyo University and has formerly belonged to Toei Animation where he learned to work as a director, and was also involved as a production assistant, storyboarder and director on episodes on series like Slam Dunk and Gegege no Kitarou.

Kakudou is currently a freelance director and a member of the animation production group "Group Ebisen" (グループえびせん).

__Birthplace:__ Yokohama, Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan
__Daughter:__ [Ryouko Maekawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120430)

__Atsushi Maekawa__ is a Japanese script/screenwriter for anime, while he also occasionally writes lyrics for music.
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/s_nobuzane)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. Shibata is a japanese animator and animatior director currently working at Toei Animation. He is the father of the mangaka [Yuusaku Shibata](https://anilist.co/staff/107002) and [Hikari Shibata](https://anilist.co/staff/127324).
